## What

This PR is a follow-up of #11445. This PR aims to unify the style of the search bar across the patterns. Keep in mind that with a different background, the search bar doesn't look great due to this issue: https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/44671

_Please consider any edge cases this change may have, and also other areas of the product this may impact._

1. Create a new post.
2. Add the patterns: `Footer with Simple Menu and Cart`, `Footer with 3 Menus`, `Centered Header Menu with Search`, ` Essential Header Dark`, `Large Header Dark`, `Large Header`.
3. Save the post.
4. Visit the post.
5. Ensure that the style of the search bar is the same.

pull_request.title: Move `Combobox` to components package
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please do not remove any information from this pull request. Instead, add N/A or leave blank if not applicable -->

## What

Moves the `Combobox` component to the components package and updates the places it is imported:

- `CountryInput`
- `StateInput`

## Why

<!-- Describe the reason for your changes. This will help the reviewer and future readers get additional context -->
As more developers integrate their extensions with WooCommerce Blocks, the case for reusing components grows. This starts the ball rolling by creating a new package. Rather than recreating components developers can access `wc.blocksComponents` and get the ones we need.

## Testing Instructions

<!-- Write these steps from the perspective of a "user" (merchant) familiar with WooCommerce. No need to spell out the steps for common setup scenarios (eg. "Create a product"), but do be specific about the thing being tested. Include screenshots demonstrating expectations where that will be helpful. -->

_Please consider any edge cases this change may have, and also other areas of the product this may impact._

1. Add items to your cart and go to the Checkout block.
2. Ensure the country input works correctly, select United States.
3. Ensure the state input works correctly, select any state.
4. Check out and ensure the order is placed correctly with the correct country and state.

pull_request.title: Playwright: Add eslint rule to prevent import `test` or `expect` from playwright library
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please do not remove any information from this pull request. Instead, add N/A or leave blank if not applicable -->

## What
This PR adds an Eslint rule to prevent import `test` or `expect` from the Playwright lib and use `@woocommerce/e2e-playwright-utils` instead. This eslint rule also automatically fixes the code by replacing `@playwright/test` with `@woocommerce/e2e-playwright-utils`.

Fixes #10505 

## Why
This is a quality of life improvement, and prevent test authors spending time debugging why utils aren't available

<!-- Describe the reason for your changes. This will help the reviewer and future readers get additional context -->

## Testing Instructions

<!-- Write these steps from the perspective of a "user" (merchant) familiar with WooCommerce. No need to spell out the steps for common setup scenarios (eg. "Create a product"), but do be specific about the thing being tested. Include screenshots demonstrating expectations where that will be helpful. -->

_Please consider any edge cases this change may have, and also other areas of the product this may impact._

1. Go to a playwright test file, such as: `tests/e2e/tests/add-to-cart-form/add-to-cart-form.block_theme.spec.ts`
2. Try importing the `test` or `expect` function from the library `@playwright/test`, for instance:
```
import { expect, test } from '@playwright/test';
```
3. See that an error appears with the message "Import test or expect from @woocommerce/e2e-playwright-utils instead of @playwright/test for additional utilities."
4. Run `eslint --fix` against the file and make sure the code is fixed with the correct import (if your editor runs eslint fix on save, you can save the file and check if the code is fixed).


* [x] Do not include in the Testing Notes <!-- Check this box if this PR can't be tested (ie: it makes changes to tests, coding standards, docblocks, etc.). -->
* [x] Should be tested by the development team exclusively <!-- Check this box if this PR should be tested by the development team exclusively (ie: it doesn't include user-facing changes or it can't be tested without manually modifying the code). -->

issue.title: Spacing Issues on Footer w/ Simple Menu & Cart Pattern

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: The issue is a request for an enhancement.

labels.name: category: styles
labels.description: Issues that involve styles/css/layout structure.

labels.name: ▫️ pattern: footers
labels.description: WooCommerce footer patterns

labels.name: patterns
labels.description: WooCommerce patterns

issue.body:
## Describe the bug

A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

## To reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to the Site Editor edit the Single Post template (any template is fine - using Single Post for this example).
2. Replace the footer in the template with the `Footer w/ Simple Menu & Cart` pattern.
3. Confirm there is no spacing at the bottom of the footer or to the left (see screenshots below).
4. Save the template and view the frontend.
5. Confirm the same spacing issues from step #3.

## Expected behavior

The footer pattern could use a little more spacing on the left and bottom to be more consistent with the right side.

## Screenshots

| Desktop | Mobile |
| ------ | ----- |
| ![CleanShot 2023-10-22 at 21 24 30](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-blocks/assets/481776/bc332c21-0e43-4977-b9a2-f825f7535456) | ![CleanShot 2023-10-22 at 21 25 34](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-blocks/assets/481776/9f5de373-5447-4213-91d7-408c0f0510d2) |

## Environment

### WordPress (please complete the following information):

-   WordPress version: 6.4 RC2
-   Gutenberg version (if installed): 16.8.1
-   WooCommerce version: 8.2.1
-   WooCommerce Blocks version: 11.4.0 
-   Site language: EN
-   Any other plugins installed: Jetpack, WordPress Importer


### Desktop (please complete the following information):

-   OS: macOS
-   Browser: Google Chrome
-   Version: 118

### Smartphone (please complete the following information):

-   Device: [e.g. iPhone6]
-   OS: [e.g. iOS8.1]
-   Browser [e.g. stock browser, safari]
-   Version [e.g. 22]

## Additional context

Add any other context about the problem here.

<!-- Please do not remove any information from this pull request. Instead, add N/A or leave blank if not applicable -->

## What

This PR is a follow-up of #11445. This PR aims to unify the style of the search bar across the patterns. Keep in mind that with a different background, the search bar doesn't look great due to this issue: https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/44671


## Why

<!-- Describe the reason for your changes. This will help the reviewer and future readers get additional context -->

## Testing Instructions

<!-- Write these steps from the perspective of a "user" (merchant) familiar with WooCommerce. No need to spell out the steps for common setup scenarios (eg. "Create a product"), but do be specific about the thing being tested. Include screenshots demonstrating expectations where that will be helpful. -->

_Please consider any edge cases this change may have, and also other areas of the product this may impact._

1. Create a new post.
2. Add the patterns: `Footer with Simple Menu and Cart`, `Footer with 3 Menus`, `Centered Header Menu with Search`, ` Essential Header Dark`, `Large Header Dark`, `Large Header`.
3. Save the post.
4. Visit the post.
5. Ensure that the style of the search bar is the same.

* [ ] Do not include in the Testing Notes <!-- Check this box if this PR can't be tested (ie: it makes changes to tests, coding standards, docblocks, etc.). -->

comment.body:
> I am not sure if we can do something related to this topic cc @nefeline

Yes, we have some control over the images used here, but not total control.

The caveat is the images used in products: we can’t allow super high-definition images for products as we download them from Pexels and upload them to the media library, so we have to be more conservative: in general, this won’t be a problem because the images of products displayed in the assembler are smaller when compared with the images of all other patterns. 

Also, even though we are using constraints for the image size to medium, Pexels can still return a wide array of sizes within this category, it depends on the quality of the image the photographers uploaded to that platform.

issue.title: Single Product Block: Image description is not centered in image gallery

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: The issue/PR concerns a confirmed bug.

issue.body:
## Describe the bug

The text describing an image in the gallery view is not left aligned or center aligned so it looks weird.

## To reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Have TT4 theme installed, on a site with Woo and Blocks installed and some sample products for convenience. You need a product with images.
2. Go to edit a post or page
3. Insert the Single Product block and save the post or page
4. View the post or page on front-end, click the product, it will go to the product page
5. On the product page click the magnifying glass button in top right of product image
6. It will display the image and the text description will have an alignment that looks wrong

## Expected behavior

It should be center aligned or perhaps left aligned, depending on the design intent, but where it's currently aligned looks wrong.

## Screenshots

[Private Zenhub Image](https://api.zenhub.com/attachedFiles/eyJfcmFpbHMiOnsibWVzc2FnZSI6IkJBaHBBMzlkQVE9PSIsImV4cCI6bnVsbCwicHVyIjoiYmxvYl9pZCJ9fQ==--1299023e66ca125d18cb458d098a1de5a3462f3a/Screenshot%202023-10-23%20at%2012.59.12%20PM.png)


## Environment

### WordPress (please complete the following information):

-   WordPress version: 6.4
-   Gutenberg version (if installed): [e.g. 12.0.0]
-   WooCommerce version: 8.1.1
-   WooCommerce Blocks version: 11.4.0-dev
-   Site language: English
-   Any other plugins installed:

### Desktop (please complete the following information):

-   OS: [e.g. macOS, Windows] macOS
-   Browser [e.g. chrome, safari] Chrome, Brave
-   Version [e.g. 22] Chromium 117

## Additional context

n/a

comment.body: This is a detail that should be addressed (not high-priority though). One of the theme-specific stylesheets in Woo Core may be causing this.  Also likely that should be watched for as a part of the work on the new Product Gallery block.
